Monster heights

By Anzer D. Fone on Thursday, January 3, 2008 - 10:56 pm:

I was wondering...can anyone list down some monster heights for each stage? Like, for example, Monster A goes up to this part of the window and the middle part of this option bar.

By Loserpie on Sunday, February 3, 2008 - 10:07 am:

I've just got back into it, personally o; I started doing a few; at the time, I thought it would be a good idea to measure them up against the drill boxes, but since the camera sometimes changes to make your monsters appear bigger/smaller, I realise I should probably have done it against the stats display (when you press square to view the monster stats, you know?) Anyway, here's what I've got. I named them Baby, Teen and Adult to represent the three growths.

TIGER

BABY - Right horn (the player's right)top of 'Meditate'
TEEN - Right horn top of 'Pull'
ADULT - Right horn middle of 'Run'

HOPPER

BABY - Head is barely at the top of 'Meditate'
TEEN - Head middle of 'Pull'
ADULT - Head is top of 'Pull'

CENTUAR

BABY - Head top of 'Pull'
TEEN - Head near the middle of 'Run'
ADULT - Head near top of 'Run'

I know it's not much, but I was raising these to be bred and fought, so it took a while. Good luck to you Anzer ;D

By Chaoswolf64 on Tuesday, February 12, 2008 - 01:05 pm:

Hmm...I was wondering, would the monster's sub affect its height at all? Like, if you have a tiger/golem mix, would it be any bigger? I hope not, for simplicity's sake. ^_^

By Loserpie on Saturday, February 16, 2008 - 01:30 am:

No, it doesn't. That would mean even MORE work for the programmers!

By Anzer D. Fone on Sunday, February 17, 2008 - 01:11 am:

Yes and no. It doesn't really affect the GENERAL height. But horns/ears/spears/etc. are marking points for different breeds for those researching on heights. Let's say, like, the horns are part of the head, but ISN'T the head. Which is why Loserpie (thanks again!) posted the marks of the Tiger's right horn, instead of the head, because it is easier to spot. Same would someone a Hare's ears.

On a side note: Whoever still hates Bobby Fatman, raise your hand! *raises hand*

By Chaoswolf64 on Sunday, February 17, 2008 - 08:22 pm:

Oh, and I read about the Bobby Fatman thing. *raises hand*

By oldie.playa on Tuesday, May 6, 2008 - 01:17 pm:

You do realize that in drill, the monster occasionally repositions itself, and the best measuring stick is when you feed them against the house? Ie, if you have the best house, you can even read their height against the bricks, which act as counters due to the measuring-stick style of said bricks?

If you were to develop an actual measure, the BEST method would be to take a ruler and count the monster at its LOWEST height, ie, if you have a bouncy one, such as a Suezo, you'd need to count it when its just finished eating and is still, or when its at its lowest, just about to jump.

By Loserpie on Sunday, September 28, 2008 - 12:17 pm:

Really late reply - went off it and just got back into it again.

Anzer: I think if the heights were to be recorded, it would have to be objective; probably by the top of the head, rather than an apendage.

Oldie: you're right - the problem is, if you use a ruler, it wouldn't be the same for every TV.

Speaking of which, what WOULD be an objective object to measure it against? It has to be something that doesn't change - the drill boxes is out, because the camera changes. But the house and stable changes too. So if there was to be a guide, that would have to be taken into account. I don't pay close attention to the different house changes, so I don't know whether it changes shape or just colour/textures. Any ideas, anyone..?
